channel.title: Posts on Amrit's Blog
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on Amrit's Blog

item.title: Heat training continues in Hua Hin.
item.description: Building off of my last post, after several setbacks over 3 days, I finally managed to hack together a function that generates the RPI and heat limited pace related plots of my previous posts all from the comfort of a RStudio chunk. First off, for the life of me I couldn’t figure out how to run a Python script from within R using the reticulate package. I spent hours to get this to work.

item.title: Heat limited running pace.
item.description: Plot heat limited running pace and a sample of my average running pace data vs. temperature and humidity. I obtained heat limiting pace data from fellrnr.com to see if my body would naturally self-limit pace based on intense heat. I wanted to spot check some of my running data taken during pretty intense heat in Bangkok while I was there during late Spring 2020.

item.title: RPI by lap on the scorching Vadhana "track".
item.description: Pinning down lap-level running data. Having to login to the Garmin Connect website and manually download running data in .csv format is starting to get pretty annoying. Searching for a more automated solution, I found a post on Reddit that pointed me to a GitHub repo containing a convenient command-line utility that allows me to download all of my Garmin lap-level activity data directly to binary .fit files. It worked like a charm.

item.title: Converting Google Classroom gradebook to standards based report cards.

item.title: Is that it?
item.description: Just like that, the 100 lap challenge is over. On my next try, I completed 100 sweltering laps. What surprised me was how tired I was at the outset from not getting enough sleep the night before. I guess it really shows what you can do if you put your mind toward something. I noticed that something’s up with Lap 50 as the RPI is unusually high. ## # A tibble: 5 x 4 ## # Groups: Date, variable [1] ## Date Laps variable value ## <date> <dbl> <fct> <dbl> ## 1 2020-03-30 50 RPI 238.

item.title: Running economy over time.
item.description: After implementing the running performance index (RPI) in my previous post, I was curious to know what my RPI was using ALL the data I had available, which I found goes back to 2009! Using more or less the same process as documented in the previous post, I import all of my available running data for runs that were greater than or equal to 3 miles and that were not run on a treadmill.

item.title: 100 lap challenge.
item.description: Having recently hunkered down in Bangkok for the foreseeable future,1 in an apartment building with a closed gym,2 I wondered what kind of exercise routine I could establish. Playing with my son in the courtyard a couple days in, I somehow got the idea of jogging a few laps around the makeshift track formed by the walking pathway – despite a heat index over 100 degrees F! Having not run in months3, I took the opportunity to challenge myself to keep going.

item.title: Pre-Assessment for Differentiation
item.description: With today’s students, technology and computers have surrounded them and often been an influential part of their lives. Some may have had free access to tinker around with computers of various sorts (e.g., cell phones, tablets, personal computers) and have shown a great deal of interest while others may not have had the same access or shown the same level of interest. For these reasons, before the Introduction to Computer Programming unit, I have chosen to first gauge students’ familiarity working with a personal computer (or laptop) system – specifically with the ability to download, install, and open the integrated development environment (IDE) that we will be using extensively throughout the computer programming class.

item.title: Using Assessment Data to Inform Instruction
item.description: The following figure is a simple illustration of how students can be grouped based on abilities using sample assessment data. Assessment scores have been averaged for each student with 1-\(\sigma\) standard deviations shown as a way to measure student score consistency. Figure 1. Student grouping based on performance. Paired with the figure above, the figure below can be used to quickly identify trends for a given student by looking at performance on various assignment categories (i.

item.title: Assessing Project Based Learning
item.description: Summary of the Student Project A “customer” is requesting a blog assessing the state of Kathmandu air pollution. Students teams will design, create, and publish a website based on research and original data analysis for a customer by integrating 21st century technology development skills. During this project students will demonstrate mastery of the following competencies1 [rubric]: Presentation (of website) + Motivation for website + Design and building experience + Discuss features + Discuss feedback received/given + Used Rmarkdown-based presentation hosted on GitHub Pages Revisions (via GitHub) + Teams assess each other by providing student feedback through GitHub’s social features2 + Edit/proofread others’ work commenting and providing constructive suggestions for changes + Teams incorporate changes as desired and can justify why they were or were not incorporated Publishing (to GitHub) + Register a new domain for website (setup Netlify w/ GitHub) + Build and deploy (when changes to website are made) Creating (a website) + Create original data analysis using tidyverse package + Create a new project in RStudio using blogdown package + Incorporates (and improves upon as needed) previously completed and submitted coursework Designing (a website) + Create an effective project outline.

item.title: Designing a High School Programming Class
item.description: Goals: Make and host an open source website. Final Project: Create a website post incorporating what you’ve learned. Make an R Presentation incorporating 10 R Markdown features. 3a. What makes a good presentation? 3b. Output to various formats (i.e., HTML, PDF, Word). Practice Exercise: Write an assignment for another class in R Markdown and submit it. Using R Markdown, make a blog post on any subject.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.
